text: Abby came and shaking her head no, but I love droughts. Difference of opinion. Thank you. We will now transition from parks and recreation to Houston Police department. At this time, I would welcome Chief Fender and Miss Rhonda. Smith, the CFO of Houston Police Department, along with Chief Satterwhite. Chief Slinkert. And I thought I saw Chief Jones as well. So good to see everybody. And of course, Ms. Rhonda Smith, the CFO. Chief, I saw you in DC. You look good. How was that plane trip? Oh, you're a smart man. Yeah. Good to see you. I just want to thank each and every council member for such support. It means a lot having the opportunity to talk to chiefs all around the nation and to have the support from the Horseshoe. It means a lot, but we'll jump right into it. Chief Troy Finner. And on behalf of the Houston Police Department, I appreciate the opportunity to submit the HPD's proposed budget budget for FY 2023. Let me first say how proud I am to be the police chief in this great city with this great department. The benefit of the burian audience. HPD is the largest agency in the state of Texas, fourth largest in the nation. We have over I'm sorry, the fifth largest in the nation. We have over 6100, both classified and civilian employees. Before moving forward, I'd like to acknowledge the men and women of the Houston Police Department, but especially the executive staff and the budget and finance staff who has worked so diligently to prepare this presentation. This year began and has been very challenging for us, as around the nation, we lost some of our own family members. But in Houston and Harris County, there was a total of six. Now, last week, seven line of duty deaths. We also faced the challenge of increasing crime. At the beginning of the year, especially, my top priority is to address those. The trends of increasing crime was to reduce the violent crime, enhance technology, and also improve the staffing. Just want to say the One Safe Houston initiative has been successful. We've been doing an excellent job looking at the numbers. Every week those numbers have been going down, and we've seen a reduction in violent crime on a weekly basis. So, again, I want to thank the mayor, I want to thank City Council for the additional opera rescue funding and fighting crime and reducing some of that crime and improving the quality of life. I want to hit on one stat before we move forward. In January, as compared to the previous year, our homicide numbers were over 70%. Today it's 7%. And that is a direct result of good policing, but also everybody working together, our citizens and the criminal justice system coming together. Technology. We have secured the following major technology milestones. Body warrant camera upgrades will allow us to purchase the next well, 300 I'm sorry, 3500 next generation body worn cameras. The HPD data center locate relocation. We completely moved the HPD primary data center to a shared space within the city data center. We've moved over 300 servers. We've implemented Shot spotters not only in the Southeast, but also in the North Division. Now, I'm sorry, our RMS system, we're in a quiet period, but we have an RFP out. That's all I'm going to say about that. But it will assist us in our fight of violent crime. We want to make our real time crime center a true strategic decision support system. The expansion of automated license plate readers in high crime areas and also cameras. So we're looking, and I want to thank certain council members for funding that. It's something that we want to move around the city, but it's not just the responsibility of the city and taxpayers. We want to get everybody on board on that. We also, in terms of staffing, we have to continue to fund the five academy classes each year. Also want to thank council for working on city audience, for the Cadillac converter audience, the noise audits audits. And also the exterior security video camera audit audits. And also the county for passing the 10% bond for defendants charged with violent crime. The presentation will begin with an overview of organizational structure. For the sake of time, I will move through these slides quickly and answer any questions at the end. Next slide. This slide shows a current organization structure. Next slide. This slide is basically the addition of the executive assistant Chief I'm sorry, the Executive chief, chief Slinker, which we added that new position at the beginning of my administration. Next slide. This is the office of the police, of the Chief of Police. Everything that's up under my command. Next slide. This slide, it looks at investigations and special operations. It's under Chief Jones. And the next slide is patrol operations on the chief satellite. Next slide, please. This is a special fund. In addition to our general funds, our organization includes operations and special funds. These are funds that are restricted. The money is restricted for restricted use. I meant to say Ms. Smith will go into further detail here just shortly. Next slide. Want to look at the breakdown of gender of our agency. The significant thing about this slide is for cities of over 1 million in population I'm sorry, we move it. One more slide. One more. Thank you. For cities over 1 million in population. And the police departments have 17% female. HPD is also at 17%. For the civilian, that's for classified. For the civilians, we're at 68% as compared to the national average of 66%. HPD is one of the most diverse law enforcement agencies in the nation. We're a majority I'm sorry. Next slide. Go to it. HPD is one of the most diverse agencies in the nation. We are a majority minority police department with 78.9% of the civilians are minority, 60.9% of classified. A closer breakdown of it looking at the classified side, 39% Caucasian, 31% Hispanic or Latino, 21% African American and 8% Asian. For the civilian workforce, we have 45% African American, 21% White, 25% Latino Hispanic and then 8% Asian. The department programming. I always like to state our mission statement. Mission statement is to hang the quality of life in the city of Houston by working cooperatively with the public within the framework work of the US constitution to enforce laws, preserve the peace, reduce fear, and provide a safe environment. Next slide. Reducing violent crime is one of the mayor's highest priorities, and we have made great strides in accomplishing the goal. Despite financial challenges and staffing, some of the core duties prevent crime, respond to calls for service, conduct investigations, arrest individuals suspected of committing crimes, coordinate with Homeland Security activities, protect lives and property during mass gathering and special events, and also enforcing traffic. Next slide. Department program continues statutory requirements of delivery of services. The Texas Code of Criminal Procedure and the city ordinance. Chapter 34, article two, defines the duties of the Houston Police Department. Recently, our team published a five year strategic plan listing five key organizational priorities. One was public safety. Building community trust was two. Three was professional development. Four was Operational Excellence and five was productivity. This budget proposal funding request for key initiatives discussed in this plan, which are first ePROs and that is employment programs for retired officers. 42 individuals will come back as retired officers and it will give us immediate assistance in investigations and other administrative duties. Five cadet classes budgeted for 75 per class. A gun intelligence center. We're working with Atl to implement a robust gun intelligence center. And also cell phones. Continued cell phones for each classified officer previously. This is funded by the Cares Act. I would like to now ask Ms. Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, to provide an overview of the 2023 proposed budget. Thank you. Thank you, Chief. Good morning everyone. My name is Rhonda. Smith, as the chief has said. And I am the deputy director for the Houston Police Department. And I echo Chief Sinner's sentiment in terms of working with such a great crew. And so I want to take just a minute point of privilege to talk about the Office of Budget and Finance who've been working tirelessly throughout the year and particularly now for the budget presentation. So I'm going to ask them just to stand so I can acknowledge them. So we're always behind the scenes, so they are a little shy, but thank you. So as we move forward, this first slide is the revenue by fund. First, I'd like to just say that the police department operates under six funds. The primary fund is the general fund, which makes up about 97% of our operations. The other funds are special funds. And so each fund has a revenue component. And this is what you see here on this slide. So for the first item, general fund and I'll be speaking from the column that's titled Fiscal Year 23 proposed Budget for the General Fund. The proposed revenue anticipated is $43.5 million. Now, it's revenue, but it's actually a reimbursement. 84% of that is the reimbursement that we receive from the airport systems. So we provide those services for intercontinental hobby and the Ellington field. The next item is our police special services fund. This is a collection of special funds for restricted use. For example, all of the training that we do that is provided by the state flows through this fund, reimbursement for what's called MoUs, or Memorandum of Understanding, which we have with other agencies, flow through this fund and funding for our combat against human trafficking, as well as cost recovery services and special funds and special events. We anticipate that that budget would be 7.9 million. And our next item, our special fund is auto dealers. And for revenue for that one, we are anticipating 8.5 budgeted for the auto dealers. And of course, with auto dealers, it's a standalone fund. And this fund is responsible for regulating automotive businesses, auto salespersons, storage lots, and towing industry. So the revenue we receive primarily is coming from fees that we charge in servicing that process. Our next item is child safety fund. And that's clearly just a flow through. Just for by way of background, in 1991, the state legislature required that any population over 850,000 should fund it. And we fund it through assessing certain fees on municipal fines. And so what we get, we pass back through. And if we don't get enough, then there's no money else, no other way to get the funding. And so that's what that child safety fund is. And of course, asset forfeiture. So under asset forfeiture. The one thing I'll say, and I know my stuff is looking at me because we cannot budget for asset forfeiture because it's on a case by case basis other than the state allows us to do some budgeting. But I will say that typically right now, we're budgeting $2 million, which is, if you look in the history, it's a little lower than anticipated. But what has happened is that we are taking the same impact everyone else is with COVID and the court systems, because in order to receive these funds, it has to flow through the court system. So we're hoping that in time that we will be back on chart. And lastly is the Forensic Transition fund. And that Forensic Transition Fund that shows 373,000,000 is really just a flow through because back in 2014, I believe we transitioned the operations of the Forensic Fund to the local government corporation. But we kept the funding, we kept the actual individuals that were associated with HPD in our funding. So we received reimbursement. So the good news is it's doing what it's supposed to. It was a transition. It started with probably more than 20. Now we only have three staff left. So we anticipate over the next several years that that will move down. So what we have in total is $65 million for revenue. Next slide, please. So this slide just highlights some of the reasons why there's a difference from year to year and the comparison is with the estimated revenue compared to the budget. So for General Fund we're showing a $1.4 million increase. As I mentioned before, 84% of the General Fund revenue has to do with our services to the police, of services to the airport system. So of course a lot of the increase has to do with the contractual obligations. In reference to the 4% increase for police and the 3% for civilian. The one thing I will highlight that the one new add on is seven positions anticipated for the last five months of the fiscal year that have to do with the integrated coordination center which is being created by the airport system and they have requested our participation in that, but of course they will be reimbursing us for it. So I'm going to skip to auto dealers and you'll see a small decrease. But really that's just because fiscal year 22 we saw uptick in the increase of selling cars that have been stored and the actual funding for that. So we tend to budget pretty conservatively. So we've gone back to what we typically would see during a year. And the last item that I will include is the forensic transition. But I've already explained that one why that's going down, so next slide please. So this is the expenditure by fund. So for General Fund, the proposed budget is $988,000,000 or a difference of 33 million. And I will explain that a little bit later on and go into a little bit more detail. In terms of the general budget for police special Fund, we have a budget of $10.9 million and most of that is personnel. But we do also have some increases because of technology increase, technology enhancements that we are anticipating this fiscal year. The only other thing that I will focus on is asset forfeiture, but I think I've kind of mentioned that before and why that number appears to be going up, but we didn't spend as much last year, but we do anticipate spending a little bit more this year. Thank you. Next slide please. This is the expenditure highlights which shows the difference. As I mentioned with General Fund there's a $33 million difference which I'll go in into the next slide and I believe I've already explained the differences in the others. So I'll move forward with the next slide please. So this is the slide that explains how we came up to the 988,000,000. If you recall, last year we had a budget adopted of 955,000,000 and throughout the year there are adjustments to the budget. For example, there are adjustments in the restricted funds that are shared funds that we are provided that number from the administration. And then we of course we have the adjustment for the 3% increase for the Hope budget is what I'd like to refer to as the three three three that we're all very ecstatic to see happen. And then we had a decrease in our health benefit. So that's primarily because we had a lot of more attrition than anticipated. So the budget was adjusted to reflect that decrease for health benefits. Then of course we have the Council council support monies that we've received about $129,000 and then that gets you and, and of course I can't, I would be remiss if I didn't add on that. We added the gunshot detection with the shot spotter and those are two locations at 350 each. So that's the 700,000. So that gets us down to what we refer to as the current budget. And the current budget is just the adopted plus any adjustments we've made during the year. And from there we get down to how we came to the current budget, to the fiscal year budget. And this pretty much shows you every item that has been adjusted. A lot of it has to do with the Hope and the contract with the police union HPU in terms of the increases, the 4% and the 3%. And of course we had an increase in the health care also. So I'm not going to go through each one. I wanted to just highlight those items that may bring up some question if you look about halfway down there's, the Cadet adjustment. So last year we had anticipated six classes, but we now know that filling up the five classes is our priority. So we readjusted that down to five classes versus six classes. And then the last several items here, it's called approved PBJs and those are requests that we've made to adjust our budget. And I'm happy to say that we had four this year. One had to do with the body worn cameras, which was approved this last fiscal year. And this 1.8 represents the storage cost for the body worn cameras. And of course, the Chief mentioned the ePRO program also. Next slide, please. So this slide represents the balance between personnel cost and non personnel costs. So interesting enough, we have 988,000,091% of that pertains to personnel cost. Last year was about 92, 93%. And you may ask what's happened? Well, we've got the ePROs program and we also have another program, I can't remember the name, but the other program which actually has added to the other side of it. So now it's 91%. So it's going in the right direction. Next slide, please. So I'm going to move through these pretty quickly because if you see with the special funds, it's mostly 50 50, mostly personnel and non personnel, it's about 50 50. So with the Police special fund it is 52% for personnel and 48% for non personnel and special funds. A lot of the personnel has to do with overtime. There are some staff, but it's primarily overtime cost that we receive fund reimbursement for. Next slide please. So this is asset forfeiture. It's the same case as 50 50 just about and that's personnel versus non personnel. So next slide please. And this is the auto dealers. The same with this one in terms of personnel versus non personnel. Next slide please. So we've put these two on the same slide. The first one is a child safety and of course that's strictly a flow through. So it's 100% or almost 100% flow through for services and for the forensic, it's 100% personnel. Next slide, please. So this gives you a historical factor in terms of how we have fared in comparison with what we've spent versus our adopted budget. And as you can see that we typically come on budget. We spend a lot of time making sure that we stay within our budget. We understand the budgets are tight and we are fiscally responsible and we want to make sure that we stand here. So this actual presentation shows that in a graphical manner. Next slide. So the next few slides you'll see that the adopted budget is much more than the expenditures. A lot of times with the special funds, if we do not have enough time to spend the money, it's just rolled over to the next fiscal year and that's happened in the first five years of 2019 through 2023. Next slide please. The same with asset forfeiture you'll see that same trend, but we are working to make sure that the revenue and the adopted budget and the expenditures are in line, but there are some times when we run out of time. Next slide, please. And this is the auto dealers, which is typically on target. Next slide, please. And of course it's the child safety which is a smaller funds. Next slide. So with that, I'm going to pass it back over to Chief if he'd like to close us out. Just again, thanks for the support of our council members and the citizens as well. But we really wanted to kind of move through quickly because I wanted to save time for questions and answers. Thanks again, Ms. Jones. And Chief Finner. It's not every day that we have the opportunity to have you and your command staff in front of us. So again, I'd like to recognize Chief Slinkert, chief Jones and Chief Satellite, and also Ray Hunt and Doug Griffin with HPOU who are valuable partners not only to the police department but to the city council as well. And also Mr. Peter Stout with the CEO of the Houston Forensic Science Lab. Our first question comes from council member Abby Cayman. Thank you, Mayor Pro TEM. And I have a list of questions, so just go ahead and put me back in queue. Chief, first off, thank you so much for your leadership and to the entire team all the way on down to each division as we continue to face not only the surgeon violent crime following the pandemic locally. But could you share what you're seeing? I know you were just in DC, what that trip was about and what we're seeing nationally and how what we are doing is either working or not working. Thank you for asking. It was a good trip for not only me, but for the mayor and for our city and visiting with the President, the Rescue Act, he pledged to continue to fund us, and that was a huge thing. But the meeting, first of all, I just want to say honor to those men and women who paid the ultimate sacrifice during that weekend of memorial. But when you're talking to other chiefs from around the nation, you understand that everybody has the same problems, with one exception. Nobody has the backlog problem that we have here in Houston, Harris County. Absolutely nobody. And in our conversations, they were amazed. But they're dealing with some of the same other issues, the gun violence, letting individuals out of jail when they're repeating time and time, violent crime. So that's the challenge. But also recruiting and just hearing some of the things that they're doing. And I told the mayor that I think I'll meet this Thursday. I want to talk to him about some of the recruiting initiatives that they are putting in place and also probably using as more funding comes in, using some of that for some incentives for individuals coming in to the academy or actually recruiting them. Mentioned recruitment. There's been conversations and questions about cadet classes. And I know you mentioned in this budget there's five, is that correct? And could you clarify, though, because we oftentimes talk about cadet classes, but we also are dealing with retention issues. So can you share with us where that brings us in terms of HPD? Yes, staffing, the recruiting, we can always improve. But the biggest problem right now is the Attrition Rate We're Agent Agency and a lot of these individuals who are leaving when they get 35, 30 years, it's hard to keep them when they're ready to go. So as we put cadets in the class on the back end, people are retiring. So that is a huge challenge right now. So it's very important that we just don't lose hope and understand and hoping that that time itself out as some of those retire and then other cadets come through our academy and come on out on the streets. Hopefully on the back end, in a few years, we'll be able to hold on to a lot more for a longer time. It's not just that we're adding additional numbers. We'll put you back in queue. Council Member Sally Alcorn. Thank you, Chair, and thank you, Chief, for the presentation. I have a question about investigative and special operations. I know there was talk about clearance rates and how we were doing better ten years ago than we were doing now. And we added, I thought some classifieds to that division. It looks like we budgeted for more last year and then hired fewer, and now we're trying to get more. Can you talk a little bit about yeah, I'm proud to say that our clearance rate, divisional clearance rate and homicide is at 80% now. That's great. When you looked at last year in 2020, those numbers were down. So we're trending in the right direction. I want to give credit to the great investigative work and also the leadership on the investigative side, chief Jones and some of our other assistant chiefs and the men and women who are doing just knockout investigations. But again, people don't give enough credit to the value of good relationships with citizens. And you see time and time again, citizens are stepping up more. And I think that's because of a better relationship and more trust building in. So it has to all gel together. But I'm excited about it, and I just pray that we continue to trend that way. That's great news. Good to hear. On the property room, how many classifieds do we have working at the property room? I'm not sure on that number. Does anybody have a property room? And if not, we'll get that to you. Okay, that's great. And I'd like to see, in addition to the clearance rate be put on the performance measures that you all include in the book, the disposition of property. I know what we receive in and what goes out. I think we're way in more. We have way more in in all categories than than what goes out. And that ties up a lot of officers. We include that council member Tiffany Thomas. Thank you, Mayor Pro TEM. Hello, Chief. It's good to see you doing this morning. I'm well. So two questions. One's an aside from the general fund, I'm pretty clear about how you're funded, but oftentimes we receive grant where council approves grant award grant applications rather to support the department. And I remember there was one item, particularly that was almost like a community mobile unit that was the application was supposed to use to do some community efforts. When do we receive information that the award was actually accepted or funded and that those capital pieces of equipment are actually within our hands? That mobile brand? I think that got it's. Chief Johnson. Commander Johnson. We just put in for a year ago. Yeah. So we'll get some follow up on that and see what we are, because it's a great idea. We want to go to our communities because of staffing. A lot of the storefronts were closed down. So if we can have a mobile outreach, I guess I used to call them Winnebagos vehicles, but we can go directly to the community. Right. Just curious about the status of that. And then secondly, I think my first year in office, I took a tour of the forensic center. I was fascinated by it, just overwhelmed with the amount of work that they do. If I understand this, this is a decrease in their budget. Is this the variance? Is that a variance? So for what we have, it's just the number of individuals that transition over from the city to the forensics. So it's just kind of like a holding pattern because that was what was agreed upon in order to keep them with the benefits of the sure. So then this leads to my question in terms of making sure your officers on the ground are doing yeoman's work around with the homicide rate. Everyone's doing their part. That's the asset. We've asked the community what type of funding would they need in order to make sure that evidence is not backlog? All of that data collection so they can keep in track with the goals that we're setting in the city. We have to stay in communication with our forensic center as we make more arrests. There is more of a demand on them, and we need to make sure that we're meeting that demand. So we've been in communication, and I'm sure they're going to be in communication with the mayor to make sure they get what they need. Sure. Wonderful. So you're not saying we need to play the mega millions in order to get this funded? Because maybe we need to play some. I think that there should be some direct conversations on need and we need to work together as a team. And the mayor has been just stand up with that, including the council. When any of us pertaining to safety of our city needs something and we present it to everybody has been very fair, and I want us to keep doing that with all, not only HPD, but with all departments in the city. Vice Mayor Pro TEM martha Castex Tatum. Thank you, Chair. Chief Finner, thank you for the presentation. Ms. Smith, thank you for always being so very thorough. I wanted to talk a little bit about ShotSpotter. We had almost a unanimous council vote on the support of ShotSpotter. Our residents are clamoring for ShotSpotter in our communities. If you can give us some insight on the value of that and if you anticipate that the cost of Shot spotter will decrease I don't know about decreasing. We hope as we add more, we can make better deals. But it's a tremendous piece of technology, gun detection. We've had cases where when they discharge a firearm, we're immediately responding to it and we have made some arrests. So as many more as we can stand up as fund and allow. But again, you look at different cities, it's not just the city government responsibility. Everybody has to kick in corporations so we can stand up more, but it's something that's needed and wanted by the chief and our men and women in uniform. So it's something I hope we can find more. But also the corporations and private entities step up and assist us with. That. And then I wanted to talk about the rollout of the outward facing cameras. If we can eventually come back to maybe public safety once that 90 day period is up, to talk about those places that have installed those cameras or the ones that have not. What we need to do to make sure that we are enforcing that ordinance. One of the biggest complaints we have in our district is the nuisance that is created at a lot of those convenience stores. And when you let that petty crime go on, it leads to bigger crime. So I think we are headed in the right direction with those ordinances. And we appreciate all that you and your entire team is doing to keep us all safe in the city of Houston. Thank you. Council Member we're very intentional on holding those convenience stores, bars, and anybody, any, established accountable for helping us fight crime. Council member. Leticia plummer. Thank you so much. Mayor Person. Thank you, Chief. Good morning. Good morning. Two questions. What is the retention rate of our cadets? Do they stay with the force? Have we found that? You know, I had some let me see if I had some numbers. When did they graduate? I forgot where I was on my page. I looked at it. Be specific. When they graduate. Yes. Let me get you a percentage. I know we have it somewhere here, but we'll get that to you. Absolutely. Okay, wonderful. Thank you. I would like to know that you're looking at graduation rate. How long? Stay on the course. Okay, I got you. What's the retention rate of our graduates? Because we're paying for them to be trained. Right. Got you. Okay. And then what would that look like in terms of increasing that number, whatever that is? We can talk offline on that. The other question is, you mentioned the Biden administration. Congratulations on meeting with the President. Thank you. Just honestly, I hear that we can put thousands of officers on the ground, but if we don't get forensics funded properly, it leads to two issues. Right. The backlog is going to continue to increase, and then people are going to be falsely accused for issues. Yes. So my question to you is maybe this is a not right now question, but I would love to see our forensics department get the money that they need. I think they need I think they're short, like, $9 million to fill that, to get that backlog handled. And also training and funding going toward our officers that collect the data, specimens, et cetera, on the ground so we can make sure whatever is collected is collected properly. Yes. And our officers are going to need training and all that they need to do to that do that well. So those are two things I would love to see line items for. Yes. Okay. Thank you. Council Member Carolyn Evan Shabaz. Thank you, Mayor Pro tim and I believe last year, council Member Pollard gave 50,000, I think, to the forensics unit. And I would like to, like they say, follow that cab. I'd like to do that as well from my council district service funds. And I urge other council members to look at that as well, because we're going to have to get these cases, get the information that is given to us examined in order to move through the court system. And so I would like to say that and challenge my colleagues to do the same. Thank you. Council member Tasha Jackson. Thank you. Hey, Chief. How are you? Good morning, Council. So I have three questions. So what is HBB's clearance rate for violent crime last year? And what is the clearance rate for crime overall? And then lastly, constituents have reached out about the cadet classes and just want to know what is HBD doing to recruits from within the neighborhoods? There's a complaint that concern that the officers that's patrolling the neighborhoods do not reflect the race, the people that they're so they want to see more black officers in the district. What are we doing to recruit the black officer? Let me start with the clearance rates. I went over the homicide. I'll have to get back with you, and we'll get some time in the day. On the other clearance rates for violent crimes. In terms of pacifically African American officers, the first thing I want to do is make sure that we're recruiting good officers. I want to look at that heart. But I understand when you have officers from the community who are committed, who knows the community, it helps. So we are doing everything we can to increase the diversity in our agency. But I also do not, and I say this with a lot of respect, I don't ever want to discount the contributions of non minority officers with our agency. And I know that you're not accident or saying that, but I want to acknowledge their work because they have been in our communities doing all much work for 25, 35 years without any complaints and retired honorably. So I do want to acknowledge that. But at the same time, what are we doing to increase minorities? We're going out to where they are, the universities. Let me stop. Keep going. Okay, universities. Some of the radio stations, hip hop radio stations, wherever they are, we instituted not the word study, but the life program. What is it, life history, where you get an individual and I'll get this quick example. We had at first, you had to have so many college hours or you had to be honorably discharged from the military. What about the young man and young lady that worked at Ups or any other job for five years and is a great individual? And we say in our agency, well, you don't have a college, you don't have a military, we don't want you. We did away with that. Okay? So we're looking at other ways that we can recruit not only minorities, but anybody to increase that pool. And we'll continue to do that. But I need help from council members and everybody else in our community. It's just not the job of the police department. I need you all to advocate for us, and I know you all do, but all citizens. It is a great career, and I know people don't think that sometimes because they listen to the negative, but this is an honorable profession, and we'll continue to do whatever we can increase those numbers. All right, so before we go to second round of questions from council members, I have a couple of questions, and it's related to some of the comments you made, specifically backlog and more demand on the Houston Forensic Science Center. Over the past couple of years, we've become very aware of a significant backlog in forensic lab testing, mostly due to COVID, mostly due to a halt in court operations, increase in homicides. We have job openings that we can't fill. What can we do? Because it seems as though the testing that we're doing today won't be available for three years. So to council Member Plummer's point and to council member Evan Shabbaz's point, if we arrest someone today for a homicide or whatever, do some testing, it's not for three years that this person actually goes to court. Thus we're seeing a lot of bad people going back on the streets. So when people talk about violence, I will point to the courts, the judicial system in the city of Houston and Harris County, but we also have to look at the Houston Forensics Science Lab. This will be the 8th year out of the past nine years that we've had a tax rate decrease. And the tax rate is a function well, your taxes on your homestead is a function of two variables. The tax rate that we have times your value of your home. That's the revenue we receive on the property tax. So we're capped by the state of Texas so that every year we have to reduce our tax rate, which means we don't get the ability to spend the money that is coming in via property taxes because it is capped, as is every major city in the state of Texas. However, the cap we're under is different than the cap. Dallas is under, san Antonio is under, and Austin is under because they're on a lesser cap. So when you look at property taxes, the tax rate has gone down eight of the last nine years. When you look at sales tax revenue, we've had some tough times during COVID but the projections look better. At the same time, our personnel costs are increasing. Police 4% salary increase come July 1 fire 6% salary increase come July 1 city Employees and municipal Employees 3% July 1 and you saw in the information we were presented that 65% of our overall budget on the expense side is due to personnel. So when you have those equations, it's a no win situation unless you go out and tell people in the city of Houston, do you want your taxes to increase? Every year I do this and I announce it to fellow council members. I look at my tax bill and I share it publicly. And in my tax bill this year that I paid in February, the amount of dollars that I gave to the city of Houston was 19% of my overall tax bill. My school district taxes are 56%. We had an election on Saturday for a bond referendum that passed overwhelmingly. But yet, every time I'm out in public, people look at me and say, your taxes are way too high in the city of Houston. And I point back to my school district taxes. Yeah, you get what you pay for. But I have no children anymore that are in the K through twelve education and I look really closely at the dollars that are spent in my particular school district. So I've rambled way too much. But we have a no win situation in the city of Houston because of the property tax cap that we're under and the sales tax revenue projections that we see coming at us. Because basically, we have those two sources. And if I ask Joe Q public if they want their taxes increased by the city, they'll say, not no, but heck no. Thank you. I wanted to follow up real quick because we got to get out about all these caps on the taxes.
